editorNotes: Aegislash now has the ability to stack both of its Charged Attacks, increasing the viability of its glassy Blade Forme. However, Aegislash's competitive prospects remain unproven. Time will tell if these buffs can overcome its cumbersome mechanics, or if its pre-evolution, Doublade, will be preferred.

Araquanid stands to indirectly benefit from the Ice buffs this season, particularly if Walrein returns. Its competitive history includes notable trophies, but is marred by inconsistency and inflexibility, which aren't improving this season. This is one to keep an eye on as the meta develops.

Azumarill has withstood the test of time and remains one of Great League's most prominent mascots. It owes this to its extreme bulk and excellent defensive typing. Azumarill's main drawback is its pacing, which leaves it outsped by the format's more aggressive picks.

It's big, it's mean, and it's back. Bastiodon may not win any popularity contests, but it is winning tournaments, and now that's everybody's problem. Bastiodon is the definition of bulk. It has two double weaknesses to crack it, and its abysmal pacing and pressure can leave it exposed in bad situations. That said, Bastiodon's playstyle is not for the faint of heart. Good predictions and commitment to alignment are keys for success.

Blastoise is the bulkiest Hydro Cannon user and can augment this even further with Skull Bash. With an excellent balance of stats, power, and speed, it occupies a small but strong spot in the metagame.
Carbink's bulk and Fairy typing aren't enough to carry it to meta relevancy. It rarely sees play over its Steel-type counterpart, Bastiodon, and shares many similar pitfalls with fewer resistances.

Shadow Charizard is a lethal powerhouse in the right hands. As a glass cannon, it depends on shields, alignment, and excellent energy management to unleash its potential. Talonflame is a more established alternative, but the extremes of Charizard's performance chart should strike fear both ways.

Charjabug boasts decent stats and neutral play, which are hard to find among other Electric types. Its Bug typing softens its matchups against Ground types, and X-Scissor is highly valuable against Grass. Crunch is an option to hit back against the meta's prominent Ghosts.

Clefable as multiple convincing Charged Attack options, and can choose to opt for power, speed, or a mix of the two. Clefable has yet to make headway into an open metagame, so its recent upgrades are currently unproven.

Clodsire has regained a strong position in the metagame despite Mud Slap users vying for its Ground role. Its flexible offenses and great defenses make it a stellar generalist. Its main drawbacks are its low Fast Attack pressure and its weaknesses to Ground, Ice, and Water.

Galarian Corsola is the favored Ghost type of the format thanks to its stats and coverage. It strikes an almost perfect balance between bulk, pacing, and just enough offensive pressure to get the job done. It pairs well with Steel and Fairy types who can guard from Normal or Dark type threats. A high rank Galarian Corsola has better neutral matchups than one with hatch IV's, and is well worth the effort in the current meta.

Corviknight's excellent stats and typing make it highly rated in simulations and harken back to the heydays of Skarmory. While Corviknight has a more neutral matchup profile, this is both a positive and a negative, as Corviknight can struggle through matchups which appear to be intuitive wins. One of Corviknight's biggest criticisms is its weak offenses, which make Corviknight better at absorbing damage than dealing it.

One of the most dominant Pokemon of the format, Cradily uses its powerful Rock Tomb debuff to augment its bulk and outlast neutral matchups. Its typing and moveset help make it even more neutral, and as such, it's the only Grass type to see meaningful competitive play. It can find a home on almost any team. That said, it's not without drawbacks. Cradily can struggle against Steel types and Ghost types. Its moderate pacing also incentivizes it to shield early. With a faster switch timer, Cradily's debuffs are also slightly less impactful.

Diggersby has fallen off in the format, overtaken by stronger Ground types and stronger Normal types. Notably, it lacks the Fast Attack pressure of Mud Slap, which has become a defining feature of the format. Its bulk still keeps it plenty competitive.
Diggersby has fallen off in the format, overtaken by stronger Ground types and stronger Normal types. The Shadow variant rarely ever sees play, since its bulk is its strongest asset.

Empoleon is among the standout Hydro Cannon users of the format thanks to its incredible pacing and Steel typing. However, its lower stat product and vulnerability to Ground types have limited its competitive success.

Empoleon is among the standout Hydro Cannon users of the format thanks to its incredible pacing and Steel typing. However, its lower stat product and vulnerability to Ground types have limited its competitive success.

Forretress is a mold-breaking Steel Pokemon which can hold its own against some of the format's top Ground and Flying types. With its bulk, Fast Attack pressure, and debuffing attacks, it sports a relatively neutral matchup profile. Except, of course, for its rare weakness to Fire. Some may find its moveset slow and awkward, but there's no doubting its growing competitive success.

Gastrodon has emerged as the premier Ground type in the format thanks to its improved Water-type coverage against its competitors. With a solitary weakness to Grass, Gastrodon is a flexible cornerstone for team building and a defining piece of the metagame.

Lapras has a long competitive history, but is currently on its way out of the metagame. It's a poster child for bulky Water types and neutral play. Recent shifts have left it without a clear role, and it now faces stiff competition among Water/Ice types.

Lapras has a long competitive history, but is currently on its way out of the metagame. It's a poster child for bulky Water types and neutral play. Recent shifts have left it without a clear role as it lacks decisive matchups in the meta.

Mandibuzz has received two recent buffs in Foul Play and Shadow Ball, giving it means to break back into the meta. However, this moveset imposes significant challenges against rival Dark types, and it's unable to fulfill the Flying role. Mandibuzz has reasons to be cautiously optimistic until it can prove its competitive edge.

Marowak continues to be a defining Mud Slap user, although it's losing ground to Gastrodon. The Shadow variant is strongly preferred, as its Fast Attack pressure can bulldoze through even negative matchups. Buffs to Ice types may threaten its position.

Galarian Moltres is a top Flying type in competitive play thanks to its strong matchups against meta defining Ground and Ghost types. It often finds significant neutral play. Its stats are more tempered than its predecessor, Mandibuzz, so it does have to watch for Ice or Rock coverage.

Murkrow is an aggressive, fast-paced alternative to Galarian Moltres, and is a blast to play. As its rankings indicate, it thrives when it has energy advantage, and this high skill ceiling has led to its rising competitive success. However, Murkrow depends much more on shields and team support. The regular version is generally preferred over the Shadow to balance its offensive power with just enough bulk to stay viable.

Shadow Scizor brings incredible Fast Attack pressure into the meta, especially against Cradily. Since Fire types are relatively rare, Scizor has seen more open play. Scizor's ability to deal damage is just as polarizing as its inability to take damage. Good prediction skills, careful piloting, and a dose of luck all help its competitive success.
Shadow Steelix is typically preferred over the regular variant for additional Fast Attack pressure and the boost to its non-STAB attacks.

True to its name, Shadow Steelix is among the standout Steel types in the format. Thunder Fang plus debuffing attacks give it a unique role. The Shadow boost helps make up for its lack of STAB, but it still struggles with its minimal shield pressure and closing power. Look to pair it with strong offensive pressure and Pokemon that can capitalize on alignment.

Outside of the simulations, Talonflame is one of the format's most dangerous sweepers. It shines with a shield advantage. Its 5-turn Fast Attack gives it a steep learning curve, difficult to master and exploitable by skilled opponents.

Shadow Talonflame takes its sweeper role to even scarier heights. It occupies a middle ground between regular Talonflame and Shadow Charizard, with a greater focus on Fast Attack pressure and Attack boosts. The simulations more readily capture its pitfalls, where it's harshly punished by Rock, Water, and Electric.

Umbreon is a blast from battles past and could see renewed play with the recent buff to Foul Play. There are reasons to be skeptical, as Umbreon has been absent since its heyday and a small power boost is unlikely to move the needle much. As of now, its competitive potential is unproven compared to more established, versatile Dark types.
